conclusion: To determine if the particle has returned to its starting point at the 3-second mark, analyze the velocity-time graph, focusing on the initial and final positions of the particle.

The image shows a velocity-time graph. The graph has a horizontal segment from 0 to 1 second with a velocity of 2 m/s, a diagonal segment from 1 to 2 seconds with a decreasing velocity, and a horizontal segment from 2 to 3 seconds with a velocity of 0 m/s.
The graph shows three segments: From 0 to 1 second, the velocity is constant at 2 m/s. From 1 to 2 seconds, the velocity decreases linearly. From 2 to 3 seconds, the velocity is 0 m/s.

premise: The velocity is constant at 2 m/s from 0 to 1 second.
The velocity decreases linearly from 1 to 2 seconds.
conclusion: From 1 to 2 seconds: The velocity decreases linearly, so the integral is 0.

premise: The velocity is 0 m/s from 2 to 3 seconds.
The integrals from each segment are 2 m, 0 m, and 0 m.
conclusion: The total displacement is the sum of these integrals: \( 2 + 0 + 0 = 2 \, \text{m} \).
Since the displacement is not zero, the particle has not returned to its starting point at the 3-second mark.
